questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office for evaluation of a blistering skin rash. He was out in the sun with his family at a baseball game several days ago. Later that evening, he developed a severe blistering rash on the forearms, hands, neck, and legs. He has tried over-the-counter topical emollients but to little effect. The patient has had similar rashes in the past that eventually self-resolved. The first of such episodes occurred around 10-years ago. Past medical history is also significant for hyperlipidemia and chronic hepatitis C virus infection. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals small ruptured blisters diffusely across the forearms, hands, neck, and lower legs.

 


A defect in which of the following steps of the heme biosynthesis pathway is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with skin blisters following sunlight exposure. Furthermore, he has had similar prior episodes and has a history of hepatitis C infection. In combination, these findings are concerning for porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), which is caused by a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.

The enzyme is responsible for converting uroporphyrinogen to coproporphyrinogen III. Defects in this enzyme lead to the accumulation of porphyrins, which can react with ultraviolet light and cause tissue damage.

PCT can be either familial or sporadic. The sporadic form is more common and usually due to hepatitis C infection. Symptoms can be triggered by factors such as sunlight exposure, smoking, and alcohol consumption. PCT is characterized by blistering skin lesions that appear most commonly on the backs of the hands. Furthermore, some patients may develop hypertrichosis and hyperpigmentation. Patients will also have tea-colored urine, since the excess porphyrins are excreted via urine and change color after being oxidized. In contrast, neurovisceral features are largely absent in patients with PCT.

Treatment includes avoidance of trigger factors, repeated phlebotomy to reduce iron levels, and low-dose regimen of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine. These medications form complexes with the excess porphyrins and promote their excretion.


Image reproduced from Flickr

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthase, which is defective in patients with sideroblastic anemia. The condition can manifest with microcytic anemia, Pappenheimer bodies on peripheral blood smear, and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow. However, sideroblastic anemia would not typically result in a blistering rash.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase is responsible for converting ALA to porphobilinogen. This enzyme is impaired in lead poisoning, which can lead to neurologic symptoms such as headaches, memory loss, and peripheral neuropathy. In contrast, this patient has a blistering skin rash in the setting of hepatitis C infection, which is more concerning for porphyria cutanea tarda.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes porphobilinogen deaminase, which is defective in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). The condition can manifest with abdominal pain, polyneuropathy, psychiatric symptoms (e.g., anxiety, delusions), autonomic dysfunction, and port-wine colored urine. However, AIP would not typically present with a blistering rash.
❌ D:
Incorrect: A defect in uroporphyrinogen III carboxylase would cause congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP). Patients with CEP can manifest in childhood with photosensitivity, blistering rashes, and hemolytic anemia. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms developed in adulthood and in the setting of hepatitis C infection, which is more concerning for porphyria cutanea tarda.
✅ E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being evaluated by her primary care physician for recurrent pancreatitis. The patient has had two episodes of pancreatitis over the past year. She consumes a balanced diet and does not drink alcohol. Family history is notable for osteoarthritis in her father. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 121/72 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. Physical examination of the skin is notable for multiple small red-yellow papules on the buttocks and shoulders. Laboratory testing reveals a serum triglyceride level of 830 mg/dL.Which of the following best describes the function of the protein that is most likely defective in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids
Binding of low density lipoprotein to its receptors
Conversion of free cholesterol to cholesteryl esters
Secretion of chylomicrons into the lymphatics

questions.solution:
This patient has type I familial hyperlipidemia, which is most often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase. Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol. The condition presents with pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas. 

After a meal, fats are taken up by intestinal cells, packaged into chylomicrons, and released into the bloodstream. Capillary lipoprotein lipase breaks down chylomicrons in order to free the triglycerides, which are absorbed by nearby tissues.  

Chylomicron remnants, which contain cholesterol and small amounts of triglyceride, then travel to the liver to deposit the leftover lipids. The liver will combine these remnants with more, newly synthesized fatty acids and cholesterol, and it will package them together into very low-density lipoproteins (VLDLs).   

VLDLs are released into the blood where lipoprotein lipase breaks them down again to release triglycerides for nearby tissues to use. As triglycerides leave the VLDL, it becomes an intermediate density lipoprotein (IDL) and eventually a low density lipoprotein (LDL). LDLs are ultimately endocytosed by liver and peripheral tissue cells expressing LDL receptors.  

Without a functional lipoprotein lipase, the breakdown of chylomicrons and their triglyceride content is prevented, resulting in massive triglyceride accumulation within the blood with subsequent clinical consequences (e.g., recurrent pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas).  





Option Analysis

✅ Breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Uptake of lipoprotein remnants  :
Incorrect: Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is involved in the uptake of lipoprotein remnants. An ApoE defect presents with premature atherosclerosis, xanthomas, and increased risk of developing acute coronary syndrome. Although this patient has xanthomas, it would be atypical for an ApoE defect to cause recurrent pancreatitis.  
❌ Binding of low density lipoprotein to its receptors:
Incorrect: Apolipoprotein B-100 mediates the binding of low density lipoproteins (LDLs) to their receptors. A defect leads to type II familial hypercholesterolemia, which presents with atherosclerosis, early onset of coronary artery disease, tendon xanthomas, and corneal arcus. In contrast, this patient has no signs of coronary artery disease or tendon xanthomas.  
❌ Conversion of free cholesterol to cholesteryl esters:
Incorrect: A defect in lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), or its cofactor apolipoprotein A-I, would impair this process. Defects in apolipoprotein A-I can lead to Tangier disease, which presents with cholesterol deposits in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymphatics. Patients with Tangier disease may also present with mild triglyceridemia. In contrast, this patient has a markedly elevated triglyceride level, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Secretion of chylomicrons into the lymphatics:
Incorrect: Apolipoprotein B-48 mediates this process. A defect in this protein is seen in abetalipoproteinemia. This condition presents in infancy with fat malabsorption and failure to thrive. Patients may also develop deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins. The patient in this vignette has none of these symptoms.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for right arm pain. She was playing with her younger brother when she was pushed down to the ground, and she subsequently felt sharp pain in the right arm. The girl was born via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 38-weeks gestational age. The patient has speech delay and mild hearing loss. Past medical history is notable for a left femoral fracture that occured after a fall from standing-height. Family history is significant for multiple fractures since childhood and hearing loss in the patient’s mother. The patient is at 30th percentile for height and weight. Vitals are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which type of collagen is most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with fractures after minor trauma, blue sclera, and hearing loss. She most likely has the connective tissue disorder osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). There are several types of OI, but the most common form is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and is due to mutations in the type I collagen genes (COL1A1 and COL1A2).

Type I collagen is abundant in bone, where it contributes to tensile and torsional strength. Patients with OI have decreased bone strength and flexibility. They are therefore at risk of developing fractures even after minor trauma. Patients may also experience hearing loss (which is partly due to fracture or dislocation of the middle ear bones), blue sclera (due to abnormally thin sclera over choroidal veins), and dentinogenesis imperfecta (opalescent teeth that wear easily due to a lack of dentin).

Option Analysis

✅ Type I:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type III:
Incorrect: Mutations in type III collagen can give rise to the vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. This condition is characterized by fragile tissues which are prone to cardiovascular complications (e.g., valvular prolapse, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection) and organ rupture (e.g. uterine rupture).
❌ Type IV:
Incorrect: Type IV collagen is defective in Alport syndrome. The main presenting signs include hematuria (which may progress to end-stage renal disease), ocular lens deformities, and hearing loss. In contrast, this patient has blue sclera and fractures occurring after minimal trauma, which are more concerning for osteogenesis imperfecta.
❌ Type V:
Incorrect: Type V collagen is defective in the classic type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can present with skin hyperextensibility, abnormal tissue fragility, easy bruising, and increased joint mobility. In contrast, this patient has blue sclera and fractures occurring after minimal trauma, which is more concerning for osteogenesis imperfecta.
❌ Type VII:
Incorrect: Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa is caused by mutations in the COL7A1 gene which affect the structure of type VII collagen. Patients can present with skin breaks and blisters that occur after minor trauma. Instead, the patient in this vignette has blue sclera, fractures after minimal trauma, and hearing loss, which are more concerning for osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a lesion on the right ear. She recently had her ear pierced, and she developed the lesion several weeks afterwards. The lesion has continued to grow in size and is occasionally pruritic. She has not experienced ear pain or hearing difficulty. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is notable for squamous cell carcinoma in a maternal uncle. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s lesion?

choices.text: Formation of granulation tissue around a foreign body
Malignant proliferation of connective tissue within the dermis
Infection of the external auditory canal

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a keloid scar, which is due to excessive deposition of poorly-organized collagen.

Keloids are benign, hyperproliferative, dermal lesions that usually occur in dark-skinned individuals of Asian or African descent. Keloid scars develop due to overproduction of type I and III collagen, which appear in an unorganized pattern under the microscope. Keloid scars usually develop at wound sites even after minor skin injuries (e.g., ear piercing sites, vaccination sites) and typically extend beyond the wound's boundaries. These scars can be raised, hyperpigmented, pruritic, and occasionally painful. Keloids do not regress and sometimes can enlarge over time.

In contrast, hypertrophic scars develop due to overproduction of type IIl collagen fibers which, under the microscope, appear well-organized and parallel to each other. Hypertrophic scars usually occur at sites of surgical wounds, burns, or laceration, and typically remain confined within the wound’s edges. Initially, these scars can be raised and erythematous, but they tend to regress spontaneously over time. Furthermore, hypertrophic scars have no genetic predisposition and can develop in individuals of all races.



Option Analysis

✅ Excess deposition of poorly-organized collagen:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Malignant proliferation of melanocytes:
Incorrect: Excess melanocyte proliferation can lead to the development of melanoma. Melanoma can manifest with changes in an existing mole or development of a new hyperpigmented skin lesion. This patient’s lesion, however, is more consistent with the appearance of a keloid.
❌ Formation of granulation tissue around a foreign body:
Incorrect: A foreign body granuloma is composed of cells such as macrophages, fibroblasts, and endothelial cells that surround a foreign body. It usually occurs in response to implantation of medical devices, prosthesis, tattoo ink, or injectable fillers. An ear piercing is unlikely to cause deposition of a foreign body and subsequent granulation tissue formation.
❌ Malignant proliferation of connective tissue within the dermis:
Incorrect: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans is a rare, soft tissue sarcoma that can arise due to malignant proliferation of dermal soft tissue. It presents as an indurated plaque or nodule that slowly enlarges over months to years. In contrast, this patient’s lesion developed shortly after an ear piercing, which is more concerning for a keloid scar.
❌ Infection of the external auditory canal:
Incorrect: Otitis externa is characterized by infection of the external auditory canal. The condition can cause pruritus, pain, hearing loss, and ear discharge. In contrast, this patient developed extensive scarring after an ear piercing, which is more consistent with a keloid scar.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a routine health examination. He was born via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 39-weeks gestational age to a 25-year-old woman. Past medical history is notable for multiple seizures episodes that occurred when the patient had mild fevers. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s weight, height, and head size were found to be between the 5-15th percentile of standard growth curves. Physical examination reveals a depressed nasal bridge, hypopigmented areas of skin, as well as depigmented, brittle hair. Diffuse muscle hypotonia is also noted. Genetic testing reveals that the patient has a connective tissue disorder caused by impaired copper absorption and transport. A mutation in which of the following genes is the most likely to account for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with Menkes disease, which is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene.

Menkes disease is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder caused by a defect in the protein copper-transporting ATPase, which is found within enterocytes. Normally, after copper is absorbed from the intestinal lumen by enterocytes, it is transported via copper-transporting ATPase from enterocytes into the bloodstream. This function is impaired in patients with Menkes disease, leading to copper deficiency.

Since copper is a crucial cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase, patients with Menkes disease have impaired lysyl oxidase activity and defective cross-linking of tropocollagen to make collagen fibrils. The disease usually manifests at around 6-months-old, and patients die in early childhood due to deteriorating neurological status. Clinical features include peculiar "kinky" hair, growth delays, neurological symptoms (e.g., seizures, hypotonia), skin hypopigmentation, and bony abnormalities (e.g., osteoporosis, spur formation).

Menkes disease should be distinguished from Wilson disease, which results from mutations in the ATP7B gene. Wilson disease is characterized by impaired hepatic excretion of copper into bile, resulting in copper acculumation, rather than its deficiency.  

Option Analysis

❌ COL1A1 gene:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder that results from a mutation in type 1 collagen genes (COL1A1 and COL1A2). The condition is characterized by fractures occurring after minimal trauma, blue sclera, hearing loss, and dentinogenesis imperfecta. Copper absorption is unaffected in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta.
✅ ATP7A gene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ATP7B gene:
Incorrect: The ATP7B gene is mutated in Wilson disease, which is characterized by impaired excretion of copper via bile and subsequent copper accumulation. Patients can manifest with liver disease, psychiatric symptoms, Kayser-Fleischer rings, hemolytic anemia, and renal disease. Intestinal copper absorption is largely unaffected in patients with Wilson disease.
❌ HFE gene:
Incorrect: HFE gene mutation causes hereditary hemochromatosis, which is characterized by excessive intestinal absorption of dietary iron. This condition results in a pathological increase in total body iron stores. Copper absorption is unaffected in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis.
❌ FBN1 gene:
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder that results from mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes for fibrillin. The condition characteristically affects the skeleton, heart, and eyes. Patients can have tall stature with long extremities, pectus excavatum or carinatum, joint hypermobility, lens dislocation, and cardiac valve abnormalities. Copper absorption is unaffected in patients with Marfan syndrome.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute-onset chest pain. The symptoms started less than an hour ago when the patient was walking up a flight of stairs. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at 28-years-old. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 117/75 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. The patient appears anxious and in mild distress. Physical examination shows xanthomas bilaterally on the Achilles tendons. Laboratory testing is notable for a total serum cholesterol of 354 mg/dL. An electrocardiogram is ordered and the results are as follows:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following conditions has the same inheritance pattern as this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has type II familial hyperlipidemia (also termed familial hypercholesterolemia). It is an autosomal dominant condition that can be broken down into two types. Type A is characterized by isolated elevation of LDL cholesterol, whereas type B is characterized by elevation of LDL and VLDL. The condition is caused by a defect or absence of apolipoprotein B-100 (ApoB-100), which helps LDL bind to receptors and be taken up by the liver.  

Since the liver cells are not able to take up LDL, the negative feedback is missing, resulting in the production of even more cholesterol. The cholesterol is sent out via VLDL, worsening the problem.  

Type II familial hyperlipidemia increases the patient’s risk of developing atherosclerosis. In fact, individuals may present with coronary artery disease as early as 20 years old. This patient, who is experiencing crushing chest pain, is likely presenting with a myocardial infarction (ST-segment elevations can be seen in leads II, III and aVF). Since the condition is autosomal dominant, it is very likely that the patient will have a family history of myocardial infarction at an early age in first-degree relatives. In addition, tendon xanthomas, particularly on the Achilles tendon, and corneal arcus are common in this type.    

Laboratory testing will be notable for markedly elevated serum cholesterol levels.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cystic fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. The condition is due to a defect in chloride-channels encoded by the CFTR gene. In contrast, this patient has type II hyperlipidemia, an autosomal dominant condition caused by absent or defective low density lipoprotein receptors.  
❌ Leber hereditary optic neuropathy:
Incorrect: This condition is transmitted via mitochondrial inheritance. It presents with bilateral vision loss secondary to optic nerve neuron death. However, the patient in this vignette has type II familial hyperlipidemia, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.  
❌ Hemophilia A  :
Incorrect: Hemophilia A is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. The condition causes increased bleeding due to a defect in factor VIII. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has an autosomal dominant  condition.  
❌ McCune-Albright syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with McCune-Albright syndrome exhibit mosaicism. This means that some of the body’s cells will have the mutation whereas others will not. The condition presents with cafe-au-lait spots, bone disorders, and endocrinopathies. By contrast, in this patient’s autosomal dominant condition, the defect is present across all cells in the body.    
✅ Huntington Disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent after a fall. The patient was running on the playground when she tripped and fell onto the mulch. She did not hit her head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is significant for several fractures that occured after minor trauma. Her parent also has a history of multiple fractures. The patient has been meeting most developmental goals but is experiencing language delays, for which she is scheduled to receive a hearing test in the upcoming week. The patient is at 15th and 20th percentile for height and weight, respectively. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bruising along the left lateral thigh, knee, and elbow. Kyphoscoliosis is also noted. Examination of the patient’s oropharynx reveals the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Laboratory results are within normal limits. Plain radiograph shows a fracture of the olecranon. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This child most likely has osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), which is a rare autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder that results from mutations in the type I collagen genes (COL1A1 and COL1A2).

Type I collagen is a critical component of bone, teeth, skin, and sclerae. OI can range from mild (type I), moderate (type III-IX), to lethal (type II) disease. The condition can clinically manifest with fractures that occur after minimal trauma. Patients can also have short stature, scoliosis, blue sclerae, hearing loss, and opalescent teeth that wear quickly (dentinogenesis imperfecta). Patients with type II osteogenesis imperfecta usually die in utero or in early infancy secondary to multiple fetal fractures and/or pulmonary failure (e.g. hypoplastic thoracic cavity).

OI should not be confused with child abuse, which can present with multiple fractures in various stages of healing, failure to thrive, and multiple bruises on the body.



Option Analysis

❌ Child abuse:
Incorrect: A history of multiple fractures in a child following minor trauma, in combination with poor dentition, should raise suspicion of child abuse. This patient, however, also has suspected hearing impairment, kyphoscoliosis, and a family history notable for fractures after minimal trauma, which are suggestive of an underlying hereditary disorder. Furthermore, dental caries, rather than dentinogenesis imperfecta, are associated with child abuse.
❌ Rickets:
Incorrect: Rickets can cause slow growth, bone deformities, and fractures due to defective bone mineralization. Severe forms may also result in abnormal tooth formation. Plain radiographs, however, will show epiphyseal widening. Moreover, dentinogenesis imperfecta, which is when patients have opalescent teeth that wear quickly secondary to a lack of dentin, and hearing loss are not typically seen in rickets.
✅ Osteogenesis imperfecta:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome:
Incorrect: Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a connective tissue disorder caused by defective type V collagen. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of the skin, joint hypermobility, and abnormal tissue fragility. Hearing loss, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and bone fractures after minimal trauma are not usually seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
❌ Osteopetrosis:
Incorrect: Osteopetrosis is a metabolic bone disease caused by defective osteoclastic resorption of immature bone. Patients can present with multiple fractures and hearing loss. However, plain radiographs in patients with osteopetrosis will typically show increased cortical thickening and bone density.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute abdominal pain. The pain developed a day ago and has been constant, diffuse, and 7/10 in intensity. She has also experienced nausea, vomiting, a tingling sensation in the bilateral hands, as well as painless, dark-red urine. The patient had similar episodes in the past following the consumption of alcohol. Past medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder, depression, and pelvic inflammatory disease. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and does not use contraception. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 138/78 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in the bilateral hands. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Implantation of embryo outside of the uterus

questions.solution:
This patient has abdominal pain, dark-red urine, and upper extremity neuropathy. Furthermore, the patient has had similar prior episodes triggered by alcohol intake. In combination, these findings are suggestive of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).

AIP is a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS) gene, which encodes the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase. Without this enzyme, porphobilinogen cannot be converted to hydroxymethylbilane, and heme synthesis is imapired. Moreover, defects in porphobilinogen deaminase cause the buildup of porphobilinogen and aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which are toxic to the body.



The condition is characterized by acute attacks precipitated by excessive alcohol consumption, starvation, and medications that induce cytochrome p450 (e.g., griseofulvin, phenytoin). Symptoms arise due to toxic metabolite accumulation. Patients can manifest with psychiatric symptoms (e.g., anxiety, disorientation), autonomic dysfunction, abdominal pain, and peripheral neuropathy. Furthermore, the excess porphobilinogen is excreted via urine and can give off a dark-red color. These symptoms can be remembered with the 4 P's mnemonic: Painful Abdomen, Polyneuropathy, Psychological disturbances, and Port-wine colored urine.


The condition can be treated with glucose and heme. These substances inhibit ALA acid synthase (first enzyme involved in heme synthesis) and prevent the formation of toxic downstream products. 

Option Analysis

✅ Congenital mutation affecting porphobilinogen deaminase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the appendix:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can present with acute abdominal pain. However, the pain is often localized in the right lower quadrant. Furthermore, appendicitis would not account for the other symptoms (e.g., dark-red urine, paresthesias, absence of abdominal tenderness with palpation) seen in this patient.
❌ Implantation of embryo outside of the uterus:
Incorrect: Ectopic pregnancy, which results from implantation of an embryo outside of the uterus, can present with severe abdominal pain. Although this patient is sexually active and has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease, her other findings (e.g., dark-red urine, paresthesias, absence of abdominal tenderness with palpation) and past episodes are more suggestive of acute intermittent porphyria.
❌ Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency:
Incorrect: A deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase would cause porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). It is characterized by photosensitivity, cutaneous blisters, and hyperpigmentation. In contrast, abdominal pain, dark-red colored urine, and neuropathy are more suggestive of acute intermittent porphyria.
❌ Inflammatory peripheral nerve demyelination:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a postinfectious, autoimmune-mediated condition that leads to demyelination of peripheral nerves. It is characterized by an ascending muscle weakness that begins in the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has abdominal pain, neuropathy affecting only the upper extremities, and dark red urine, which are more suggestive of another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of frequent gum bleeding. For the past three months, the patient’s gums have bled easily whenever he brushes his teeth. He has also noticed that he tends to bruise even after minor injuries. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has been living alone for the past 4 years, since his life partner passed away from cardiac arrest. His diet mostly consists of bread and canned meat products. The patient drinks alcohol occasionally but does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swollen and tender gums that bleed on probing. Skin examination demonstrates scattered ecchymoses and coiled hair. Which of the following steps in collagen production is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presents with gum bleeding and tenderness, coiled hair, and scattered ecchymosis in the setting of consuming a nutritionally-deficient diet. He likely has scurvy (vitamin C deficiency).

Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for forming cross-links between collagen molecules. Vitamin C deficiency results in reduced collagen production as well as production of collagen with lower tensile strength. This abnormality gives rise to fragile capillaries that are prone to bruising. Patients can also present with gingivitis (gum bleeding, receding gums, dental caries), poor wound healing, perifollicular hemorrhage, hemarthrosis, and coiled hair.

Other collagen disorders are summarized in the following table:



Option Analysis

✅ Proline residue hydroxylation:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Glycosylation of hydroxylysine residue:
Incorrect: The glycosylation of pro-α-chain hydroxylysine residues and the formation of procollagen are defective in osteogenesis imperfecta. The condition is characterized by fractures and bone deformities after minimal trauma, blue sclerae, and dental abnormalities such as opalescent teeth that wear easily. Gum bleeding and ecchymosis are not typically seen. Furthermore, this patient has no history of fractures.
❌ Triple helix formation:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by impaired formation of the procollagen triple helix due to impaired glycosylation of pro-α-chain hydroxylysine residues. The condition is characterized by multiple fractures and bone deformities after minimal trauma, blue sclerae, and dental abnormalities such as opalescent teeth that wear easily. In contrast, this patient has no history of fractures or bony deformities.
❌ Cross-linking of tropocollagen:
Incorrect: Lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linkage (by copper-containing lysyl oxidase) to make collagen fibrils is defective in Menkes disease. Menkes disease is characterized by brittle, “kinky” hair, developmental delay, failure to thrive, and hypotonia. In contrast, gum bleeding and ecchymosis are not typically seen.
❌ Procollagen peptidase activity:
Incorrect: Procollagen peptidase deficiency results in the formation of soluble collagen that does not properly cross-link. This defect is present in Ehler-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by joint instability, hyperextensible skin, fragile tissue with easy bruising, and poor wound healing. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms developed in the setting of a nutrient-poor diet, which is more concerning for vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of red colored urine. The patient has not experienced pain with urination, urinary frequency, or urgency. He has never experienced similar symptoms before. According to his parents, the patient has had fever and rhinorrhea for the past 2 days. Past medical history is notable for sensorineural deafness requiring hearing aids. He is otherwise healthy and enjoys being in the 1st grade. Family history is significant for end-stage renal disease in the patient’s maternal grandfather. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F ), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing boy in no acute distress. Cardiac, respiratory, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Urinalysis is notable for microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria. The type of collagen defective in this patient's condition is most extensively found in which of the following body tissues?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sensorineural hearing loss, hematuria, and hypertension. He likely has Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome is usually inherited in an X-linked pattern and occurs due to mutations in type IV collagen. Type IV collagen is primarily found in the glomerular basement membrane of the kidneys, lens of the eye, and cochlea.

Age of symptom onset can vary markedly among individuals depending on the underlying genetic defect, with some developing symptoms in infancy, whereas others may be asymptomatic until adulthood. Patients can present with intermittent hematuria. This symptom occurs because defects in type IV collagen lead to thinning and splitting of the basement membrane, which allows erythrocytes to pass from the capillaries into the urine. The mutated type IV collagen also impairs cochlear function, resulting in sensorineural hearing loss, and causes lens deformities, leading to impaired vision.

Diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing and kidney biopsy. The biopsy can be examined under an electron microscope, which will show longitudinal splitting of the glomerular basement membrane.

Another condition affecting the glomerular basement membrane is Goodpasture syndrome, which is caused by autoantibodies targeting type IV collagen. Unlike Alport syndrome, however, Goodpasture syndrome is an acquired condition.



Option Analysis

❌ Bones:
Incorrect: Type I collagen is commonly found in bones. Defects in type I collagen can lead to osteogenesis imperfecta, which is characterized by fractures after minor trauma, blue sclera, hearing loss, and dentinogenesis imperfecta. Hematuria is not typically seen in osteogenesis imperfecta.
❌ Cartilage:
Incorrect: Type II collagen is found in cartilage, the vitreous of the eyes, and the nucleus pulposus of vertebral discs. Defects in type II collagen would not lead to hematuria in combination with sensorineural hearing loss.
✅ Basement membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Blood vessels:
Incorrect: Type III collagen is abundant in blood vessels. Defects in type III collagen can lead to the vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by cardiovascular complications (e.g., valvular prolapse, aortic aneurysm) and organ rupture (e.g. uterine rupture). However, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome would not account for the patient’s hematuria and hearing loss.
❌ Granulation tissue:
Incorrect: Type III collagen is also abundant in granulation tissue. However, abnormalities in type III collagen would not account for the hematuria, hypertension, and sensorineural hearing loss experienced by this patient.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, nausea, and confusion. The symptoms began around four-days ago following a binge-drinking episode. Her pain is currently rated as a 6 out of 10 in severity. Furthermore, she has been experiencing poor sleep quality, increased forgetfulness, and a tingling sensation in the lower extremities. The patient has had several similar episodes in the past, which would last for a week and subsequently resolve spontaneously. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/68 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diffuse abdominal pain that is not exacerbated with palpation. No rebound tenderness or localizing signs are present. Serum lipase and liver function tests are within normal limits. A urine sample is obtained and is shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s condition is most likely a result from a defect in which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, paresthesias, and reddish-brown urine. Furthermore, she has had similar symptoms in the past that subsequently self-resolved. She likely has acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which is caused by defects in porphobilinogen deaminase.

Porphyrias are metabolic disorders caused by altered activities of enzymes within the heme biosynthetic pathway. These conditions lead to the accumulation of heme precursors. Most porphyrias are hereditary, with the exception of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), which is usually acquired. Porphyrias are classified as hepatic or erythropoietic based on whether the heme products first accumulate in the liver or bone marrow.

Hepatic porphyrias typically present in adults with neurologic symptoms, including neuropathic abdominal pain, peripheral motor neuropathy, and mental disturbances. In contrast, erythropoietic porphyrias typically present shortly after birth or in early childhood with cutaneous photosensitivity.

The different types of porphyrias include porphyria cutanea tarda (most common), acute intermittent porphyria, aminolevulinic acid dehydratase deficiency porphyria, hereditary coproporphyria, variegate porphyria, and congenital erythropoietic porphyria.



Option Analysis

❌ Galactose metabolism:
Incorrect: Disorders of galactose metabolism (e.g., galactokinase deficiency, classic galactosemia) are autosomal recessive conditions and manifest after the infant begins breastfeeding. Classic features may include failure to thrive, jaundice, hepatomegaly, infantile cataracts, and intellectual disability. None of these symptoms are present in this patient.
✅ Heme synthesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenylalanine metabolism:
Incorrect: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a disorder characterized by impaired breakdown of phenylalanine. The condition can present with cognitive impairment, seizures, microcephaly, and a “musty” body odor. In contrast, this patient has intermittent episodes of abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, paresthesias, and port-wine colored urine, which are more concerning for acute intermittent porphyria.
❌ Fructose metabolism:
Incorrect: Disorders of fructose metabolism usually manifest with symptoms once a child begins consuming fructose-containing supplemental foods, such as fruit, juice, or honey. Essential fructosuria is largely asymptomatic, whereas hereditary fructose intolerance can manifest with hypoglycemia, vomiting, jaundice, and cirrhosis. In contrast, these conditions would not cause intermittent episodes of diffuse abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, paresthesias, and port-wine colored urine.
❌ Glycogen storage:
Incorrect: The major manifestations of disorders of glycogen metabolism affecting the liver are hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly and, for those affecting muscle, additional symptoms include muscle cramps, exercise intolerance, progressive weakness, and variable cardiac involvement. This patient has abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, peripheral neuropathy, and port-wine colored urine, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for acute onset chest pain. Her pain is localized to beneath the sternum. The symptoms began 45 minutes ago when the patient was on the couch watching television. Family history is notable for psoriatic arthritis in her mother; she denies any early-onset coronary artery disease and familial history of myocardial infarctions. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 125/83 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. The patient appears anxious and in distress. Physical examination shows the findings below. Laboratory testing is notable for a total serum cholesterol of 290 mg/dL and serum triglyceride of 235 mg/dL. Which of the following additional skin findings would be most likely expected in this patient?



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Yellowish-brown nodules on the skin and oral mucosa
Silvery plaques on the extensor surfaces
Subcutaneous nodules on the Achilles tendon

questions.solution:
This patient has type III familial hyperlipidemia (also termed familial dysbetalipoproteinemia), an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defective apolipoprotein E (ApoE). ApoE assists with the uptake of chylomicron remnants and VLDL by the liver. As a result, patients with type III familial hyperlipidemia have elevated chylomicron and VLDL levels.  

The condition is characterized by development of premature atherosclerosis and early-onset coronary artery disease. However, unlike type II hyperlipidemia in which patients have tendon xanthomas, patients present with palmar xanthomas.  

Laboratory testing will reveal elevated serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels.  


Option Analysis

❌ Yellowish-brown nodules on the skin and oral mucosa:
Incorrect: This describes an xanthoma disseminatum, which is most often seen in patients with non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis can affect the skin, mucosal membranes, and cause diabetes insipidus secondary to pituitary gland infiltration. However, patients with this condition do not experience premature atherosclerosis or early-onset coronary artery disease.    
❌ Silvery plaques on the extensor surfaces:
Incorrect: This describes psoriasis plaques, which can be seen in patients with psoriatic arthritis. The patient’s family history places her at increased risk of developing this condition. However psoriatic arthritis also presents with joint pain and stiffness, which are absent in this patient.   
❌ Subcutaneous nodules on the Achilles tendon:
Incorrect: This describes an Achielles xanthoma, which is most often found in patients with type II familial hyperlipidemia. Patients with this condition can also develop coronary artery disease at an early age  However, type II familial hyperlipidemia is an autosomal dominant condition, so a family history of early-onset myocardial infarction is expected.  
❌ Periumbilical ecchymosis and discoloration:
Incorrect: This describes Cullen’s sign, which is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis. Patients with type I or IV familial hyperlipidemia are at increased risk of pancreatitis, which typically presents with epigastric pain radiating towards the back. In contrast, this patient has type III familial hyperlipidemia, which is not associated with pancreatitis.   
✅ Yellowish plaques on the palms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency room because of a possible elbow dislocation. The patient was playing on the playground with her nephew when she tripped and fell onto her outstretched right arm. She has had multiple joint dislocations since childhood, including both elbow joints. The patient has also experienced easy bruising and poor wound healing following minor cuts. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s father. Her height is 157 cm and weight is 56 kg (123.4 lb). Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several wide atrophic scars on the upper and lower extremities. There is a prominent right olecranon, and the right forearm appears foreshortened. Sensation is intact, though strength testing is limited due to pain. Radial pulses are present bilaterally. Skin and joint examination are shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of multiple joint dislocations, hyperelastic skin, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. Her symptoms are likely due to the classical type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), which is caused by mutations in type V collagen.

EDS is a group of connective tissue disorders that arise due to abnormalities in collagen synthesis and structure. The condition is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, though in some cases, the pattern of inheritance is autosomal recessive. EDS can be subdivided into the classical type and vascular type.

The classical type is due to mutations in type V collage, which is found in skin, bones, tendons, and ligaments. Patients can present with joint hypermobility, hyperelastic skin, tissue fragility, and poor wound healing.

The vascular type is due to mutations in type III collagen, which is found in blood vessels and hollow organs. Patients present with not only the symptoms seen in classical EDS but also cardiovascular complications (e.g., valvular prolapse, aneurysm formation, aortic dissection) and increased risk of organ rupture (e.g. uterine rupture).

Option Analysis

❌ Excess collagen deposition:
Incorrect: Keloids result from excess collagen deposition during wound healing. Keloids can present as raised, pruritic or painful nodules that grow beyond the borders of the wound.  However, this patient presents with poor wound healing, joint hypermobility, and hyperextensible skin, which are more concerning for Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
❌ COL1A1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder that results from a mutation in the COL1A1 and COL1A2 genes, which encode for type 1 collagen. The condition is characterized by fractures following minor trauma, blue sclera, hearing loss, and dentinogenesis imperfecta. In contrast, this patient does not have a history of prior fractures that occurred after minimal trauma.
✅ Defective type V collagen:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Defective fibrillin glycoprotein:
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder that results from defective fibrillin-1 protein. It characteristically affects the skeleton, heart, and eyes. Patients are often tall and have long extremities. They may have pectus excavatum or carinatum, joint hypermobility, lens dislocation, and cardiac valve abnormalities. This patient’s normal height, poor wound healing, joint hypermobility, and hyperextensible skin are more suggestive of EDS.
❌ Defective Menkes protein:
Incorrect: Menkes disease is a connective tissue disorder that results from impaired copper absorption and transport. Menkes disease is characterized by brittle, “kinky” hair, developmental delay, failure to thrive, and hypotonia. Poor wound healing, joint hypermobility, and hyperextensible skin are instead more suggestive of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of fever, cough, and night sweats. The patient has felt fatigued over the past six-months and has experienced a 15 lb (6.8 kg) weight loss. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg. A chest radiograph shows a cavitary lesion in the left upper lobe and an interferon-gamma release assay is positive. The patient is started on appropriate antimicrobial therapy. Three months later, he is seen in the office for follow-up. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:

 Laboratory Value  Result (U.S. Conventional Units)  Results (S.I. Units) 
 Hemoglobin  9.2 g/dL  5.71 mmol/L 
 Leukocyte count  11,000/mm3  11.0*109/L 
 Platelet count    230,000/mm3  230*109/L 
 Mean corpuscular volume  75 μm3  75 fL 


A peripheral blood smear shows Pappenheimer bodies. Bone marrow aspirate is subsequently obtained and demonstrates the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following processes is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Conversion of uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III
Conversion of aminolevulinic acid to porphobilinogen
Conversion of glycine and succinyl-CoA to aminolevulinic acid

questions.solution:
This patient has microcytic anemia, Pappenheimer bodies on peripheral smear, and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow aspirate. In combination with recent isoniazid use (antimicrobial therapy for tuberculosis), these findings are suggestive of sideroblastic anemia.



The condition is characterized by reduced conversion of glycine and succinyl-CoA to aminolevulinic acid. This step is catalyzed by aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthase and is the rate-limiting step in heme synthesis. Sideroblastic anemia can either be inherited or acquired. The inherited form is caused by X-linked mutations in the ALA synthase gene. Acquired causes include:

  • Excessive alcohol consumption: leads to mitochondrial damage and nutritional deficiencies. 
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency: commonly occurs as a result of isoniazid treatment for tuberculosis, since the drug attaches to and inactivates vitamin B6.
Due to impaired heme synthesis, there is an excess of iron that accumulates in organs throughout the body, particularly the heart, liver, spleen, kidneys, and intestines. The condition can manifest with fatigue, heart disease, liver damage, enlarged spleen, kidney failure, and diarrhea.

Iron studies will show a high serum iron, increased ferritin levels, and decreased total iron-binding capacity. Ringed sideroblasts, which consist of iron-laden mitochondria surrounding the nucleus, can be seen in the bone marrow. Pappenheimer bodies, which are basophilic granules of iron, can be seen in red blood cells.

Sideroblastic anemia can be differentiated from lead poisoning as follows:



Option Analysis

❌ Conversion of uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III:
Incorrect: Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is caused by a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. PCT is characterized by blistering skin lesions that most commonly appear on the dorsum of the hands. The condition is associated with hepatitis C infection. In contrast, this patient has no cutaneous lesions.
❌ Conversion of porphobilinogen to hydroxymethylbilane:
Incorrect: Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is caused by defects in the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase, which converts porphobilinogen to hydroxymethylbilane. In AIP, toxic metabolites (e.g., porphobilinogen, aminolevulinic acid) accumulate, giving rise to symptoms such as abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, peripheral neuropathy, and port-wine colored urine.
❌ Conversion of aminolevulinic acid to porphobilinogen:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning inhibits aminolevulinic acid dehydratase activity, thereby preventing conversion of aminolevulinic acid to porphobilinogen. Lead poisoning also inhibits ferrochelatase, which adds ferrous iron to protoporphyrin. The buildup of heme precursors and the direct effects of lead on neurons lead to headache, memory loss, and peripheral neuropathy. This patient does not have the aforementioned symptoms.
❌ Conversion of homocysteine to methionine:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 is a cofactor used in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Vitamin B12 deficiency manifests with macrocytic, not microcytic, anemia. Furthermore, it does not lead to basophilic stippling, as seen here. Other symptoms associated with vitamin B12 deficiency (e.g., subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, dementia) are also not present in this patient.
✅ Conversion of glycine and succinyl-CoA to aminolevulinic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents due to poor weight gain despite adequate breastmilk intake. According to the father, the patient also appears “weaker” than other children. The patient’s head often droops, and he has been unable to roll from a prone to supine position by himself. He was born at term via cesarean section due to failure to progress. Family history is insignificant. Vitals are unremarkable. The patient is at the 4th percentile for weight.  Physical examination reveals a frail and pale infant. Laboratory testing is shown below. Urinary orotic acid levels are elevated. A defect in which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient’s findings?  

Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  24% 
 Mean corpuscular volume  110 µm3 
 Leukocyte count   5,000/mm3 
 Platelets count  300,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This male infant presents with poor weight gain, weakness, and delay in meeting developmental milestones. Laboratory testing is notable for macrocytic anemia and elevated urinary orotic acid levels. These findings are concerning for orotic aciduria.  

Hereditary orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that results in a deficiency of the enzyme uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. UMP synthase is an important enzyme in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines. UMP synthase mediates the conversion of orotic acid to UMP, which is subsequently used to make the pyrimidine bases required for DNA and RNA synthesis.  

Deficiency in UMP synthase results in an inability to synthesize pyrimidines, which in turn, halts DNA and RNA synthesis as well as cellular division.  

Patients with hereditary orotic aciduria typically present with megaloblastic anemia in the first months of life. The condition is refractory for vitamin B12 or folate supplementation. In addition, orotic acid will accumulate, leading to increased levels in the blood and eventually the urine. The orotic acid can form crystals in the urine, which can cause urinary tract obstruction. If inadequately treated, patients can develop neutropenia, failure to thrive, growth retardation, developmental delay, and intellectual disability.  



Option Analysis

✅ Uridine monophosphate synthase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ornithine transcarbamylase:
Incorrect: Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of proteins in the urea cycle. Although OTC deficiency results in elevated urinary orotic acid levels, these patients also have increased ammonia levels. Furthermore, patients with OTC deficiency do not typically have megaloblastic anemia.
❌ Ribonucleotide reductase:
Incorrect: In order for nucleobases to be used in DNA synthesis, the ribose sugars need to be of the deoxy form. This step of the biochemical process is carried out by ribonucleotide reductase. While ribonucleotide reductase deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not lead to increased urinary orotic acid levels.
❌ Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: Patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome have decreased activity of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), an enzyme involved in the purine salvage pathway. Although patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may have megaloblastic anemia, uric acid levels are also elevated. Furthermore, elevated urinary orotic acid levels are not seen in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
❌ Thymidylate synthase.:
Incorrect: Thymidylate synthase is responsible for converting deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP). A deficiency in folate or vitamin B12 can lead to decreased thymidylate synthase activity and megaloblastic anemia. However, patients would not typically have elevated urinary orotic acid levels.

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman comes to the physician for a routine visit. The patient is at 19-weeks gestational age. Last week, an ultrasound was performed and the fetus was determined to be male. She is concerned that her newborn child may be affected by Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, given two of her three brothers have been diagnosed with the condition. If the fetus has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which of the following metabolic processes will most likely be impaired?

choices.text: Conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate
Conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate
Conversion of inosine monophosphate to guanosine monophosphate
Conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid
Conversion of carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline

questions.solution:
This patient is concerned that her fetus may have Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.  

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HPRT1 gene, which is found on the X-chromosome. This mutation leads to a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).  

HGPRT plays a crucial role in the purine salvage pathway by converting hypoxanthine and guanine to inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP), respectively. Defects in HGPRT result in two complications. First, there is an inability of cells to recycle inosine and guanosine to make purines. The excess hypoxanthine and guanine are instead converted to uric acid. Second, to make up for the lack of recycling, de novo purine synthesis increases, which results in even more purines being degraded to uric acid.  

As a result, patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome will develop hyperuricemia. Clinically, the condition can manifest with symptoms including self-mutilating behavior, gout, cognitive impairment, and choreoathetosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate:
Incorrect: The conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate is mediated by uridine monophosphate synthase. This enzyme is deficient in patients with orotic aciduria, not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. 
❌ Conversion of inosine monophosphate to guanosine monophosphate:
Incorrect: Inosine monophosphate (IMP) is converted to guanosine monophosphate by the enzyme inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, which is inhibited by the drug mycophenolate. Patients with  Lesch-Nyhan syndrome have a deficiency in the enzyme HGPRT. HGPRT is responsible for converting hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate.
❌ Conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid:
Incorrect: Hypoxanthine is a product of DNA breakdown and is further degraded by xanthine oxidase into uric acid to be excreted via urine. Patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome have increased conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid since hypoxanthine cannot be recycled to inosine monophosphate.
❌ Conversion of carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline:
Incorrect: The conversion of carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline is a step in the urea cycle mediated by the enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase. This enzyme is deficient in patients with ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents due to poor growth. The mother is concerned that he is growing slower than other children. The patient is breastfed five times daily and recently started eating solid foods. The patient produces seven wet diapers daily and the urine frequently has a sandy orange appearance. He has not yet been able to sit upright or crawl. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 100/56 mmHg, and pulse is 120/min. Weight is at the 5th percentile, height is at the 3rd percentile, and head circumference is at the 10th percentile. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have diffuse hypotonia. Laboratory testing is shown below. If untreated, this patient will most likely develop which of the following symptoms?  

Laboratory Value  Result
 Hemoglobin   12 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  110 µm3 
 Platelets count  200,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  5,000/mm3 
 Serum Sodium  139 mEq/L 
 Serum Potassium  3.8 mEq/L 
 Serum Calcium   8.6 mg/dL 
 Serum uric acid*  9.3 mg/dL 
*Reference Range: 3.7-8.6 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This infant has poor growth and hypotonia. Laboratory testing reveals macrocytosis and hyperuricemia. In combination, these findings are concerning for Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which can also manifest with choreiform movements.  

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the protein hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Without HGPRT, patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome cannot recycle purines. Therefore, all purines undergo metabolism into uric acid, resulting in hyperuricemia.  

Symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome typically manifest during the first year of life. Excess renal excretion of uric acid can lead to the formation of small orange urate crystals that are passed with the urine. This can be described as “orange sand” in the diapers. Moreover, patients can develop nephrolithiasis and subsequent nephropathy.    

Urate crystals can also deposit under the skin and appear as chalky lumps or nodules termed tophi. Likewise, crystals can deposit within joints and cause gout.    

For unknown reasons, elevated uric acid levels cause a drop in dopamine levels. As a result, patients often have intellectual disability, aggressive behavior, and self-mutilation (e.g., head banging, finger biting). Finally, patients may have neuromuscular problems like hypotonia, chorea (involuntary jerking movements), dystonia (involuntary muscle contractions), and delays in reaching childhood milestones.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chorea:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disease caused by a deficiency in lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase (acid maltase). These patients can develop hypotonia and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. However, patients with Pompe disease would not have hyperuricemia.
❌ Hypoketotic hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Primary carnitine deficiency is a genetic disorder that results in impaired carnitine-mediated uptake of long chain fatty acids (LCFA) into the mitochondria. Without carnitine, LCFAs accumulate within the cytosol and cause cellular toxicity. Patients often have hypoketotic hypoglycemia, weakness, hypotonia, and cardiomyopathy. However, it is not associated with hyperuricemia.
❌ Gastric rupture:
Incorrect: Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hypotonia, intellectual disability, hyperphagia, and obesity. Since patients with Prader-Willi syndrome have difficulty controlling their eating behavior, they are at increased risk of gastric rupture. However, hyperuricemia is not present in patients with Prader-Willi syndrome.  
❌ Cerebral aneurysm :
Incorrect: Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by defects in the Menkes protein, which leads to impaired copper absorption and metabolism. Patients often have brittle hair, growth retardation, and hypotonia. However, Menkes disease would not cause hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought by his parents for a wellness visit. According to the mother, the patient has had poor weight gain despite getting adequate nutrition via a combination of breastmilk and solid foods. In addition, the patient has difficulty rolling from a prone to supine position or sitting upright unassisted. Vitals are within normal limits The patient is at the 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals a frail and pale infant. Enzymatic testing is performed and confirms an absence of uridine monophosphate synthase activity. Which of the following findings is likely to be found on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient has developmental delay, poor weight gain, and pallor. Laboratory testing reveals macrocytic anemia and an absence of uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase activity. He likely has orotic aciduria, which can be managed with uridine supplementation.  

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive condition that results in a deficiency of the enzyme uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. This defect results in an inability to convert orotic acid to UMP, which is needed for DNA and RNA synthesis.    

Patients with orotic aciduria typically have megaloblastic anemia refractory to vitamin B12 and folate supplementation. In addition, serum and urinary uric acid levels will be elevated. The diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing or enzymatic activity testing.    

Treatment involves administering uridine supplements (e.g., uridine monophosphate, uridine triacetate). These supplements provide a substrate that bypasses the mutated enzyme and aids in pyrimidine synthesis.  

It is important to differentiate orotic aciduria from ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, which occurs due to a defect in the urea cycle. Both conditions present with increased serum and urine orotic acid. However, patients with OTC deficiency will also have hyperammonemia due to an inability to break down proteins. Furthermore, megaloblastic anemia is absent in OTC deficiency.   

Option Analysis

✅ Megaloblastic anemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disease caused by a deficiency in lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase (acid maltase). These patients can develop hypotonia and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 
❌ Hypoketotic hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Primary carnitine deficiency is a genetic disorder that results in impaired carnitine-mediated uptake of long chain fatty acids (LCFA) into the mitochondria. Without carnitine, LCFAs accumulate within the cytosol and cause cellular toxicity. 
❌ Gastric rupture:
Incorrect: Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by hypotonia, intellectual disability, hyperphagia, and obesity. Since patients with Prader-Willi syndrome have difficulty controlling their eating behavior, they are at increased risk of gastric rupture.
❌ Cerebral aneurysm:
Incorrect: Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by defects in the Menkes protein, which leads to impaired copper absorption and metabolism. Patients often have brittle hair, growth retardation, and hypotonia.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician due to persistent diarrhea for months. She has been hospitalized three times in the last two months due to respiratory infections that required intravenous antibiotics. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 98/56 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, the tonsils are absent. An eczematous rash is noticed over the face, limbs, and trunk. She is at the 4th percentile for weight and 5th percentile for height. Both parents are healthy; however, the patient had a brother who died at the age of two due to a severe respiratory infection. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following best explains this patient's condition?

Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  90 fL 
 Neutrophil count  1000/mm3  
 T lymphocyte count   300/mm3 
 B lymphocyte count   170/mm3 
 Platelet count   160,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic diarrhea, recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and eczematous rashes. Laboratory testing reveals decreased T and B-lymphocyte counts. The patient likely has severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).  

SCID is a life-threatening disorder characterized by B-cell and T-cell deficiency. SCID is most often caused by an X-linked recessive mutation in the gene encoding the common gamma chain, which results in a deficiency of interleukin-2 receptors. However, another important cause is an autosomal recessive mutation in the adenosine deaminase (ADA) gene.  

ADA gene mutations result in a deficiency of adenosine deaminase, which breaks down DNA by converting deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP) to deoxyinosine monophosphate (dIMP). dIMP is further metabolized into uric acid and excreted via urine.



ADA deficiency leads to dATP accumulation, most notably within lymphocytes due to their high repicalition rate, and causes cellular damage and impaired replication. These changes lead to a significant decrease in the number of T-cells, B-cells, and NK cells.  

Patients with SCID present in the first months of life with recurrent infections. Patients can have chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and skin rashes. Physical examination can reveal the absence of lymphoid tissue (e.g., tonsils). Laboratory testing will show severe lymphopenia.    

Definitive treatment of SCID involves hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, which helps restore immune function.  



Option Analysis

✅ Mutation in adenosine deaminase gene  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mutation in CFTR gene :
Incorrect: Mutations in the CFTR gene can cause cystic fibrosis, which is an autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with cystic fibrosis often present with chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and recurrent respiratory infections. However, the absence of tonsils and lymphopenia makes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) a more likely diagnosis.
❌ Mutation in bruton kinase gene  :
Incorrect: X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is due to mutations in the Bruton kinase gene. This mutation results in a deficiency of bruton kinase, which is a tyrosine kinase responsible for B-cell maturation. Since XLA is an X-linked recessive disorder, it predominantly affects boys. In addition, T-cells are not affected in XLA.
❌ Microdeletion of chromosome 22 :
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome is due to microdeletion of chromosome 22q11 and failure to develop the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. These abnormalities result in a lack of thymus and parathyroid glands, thereby causing T-lymphocyte deficiency and hypocalcemia. In addition, patients often have facial abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate) and cardiac defects (e.g., truncus arteriosus), none of which are present in this patient. 
❌ Mutation in WAS gene:
Incorrect: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS gene. The condition can present with thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and eczema. Although this patient has had recurrent infections and an eczematous rash, she has a normal platelet count. Furthermore, since the condition is X-linked recessive, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is predominantly seen in young people assigned male at birth.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a routine examination. The patient was born via vaginal delivery at 38-weeks gestational age and examination at time of birth was unremarkable. Today, the patient’s temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 102/57 mmHg, and pulse is 100/min. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have diffuse muscle hypotonia. Height and weight are below the 5th percentile for his age. Enzymatic testing reveals diagnostic findings consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This disease is due to a defect in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
This male infant presents with hypotonia and poor growth. Enzymatic testing reveals decreased activity of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). In combination, these findings are diagnostic of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which can be treated with medications such as allopurinol and febuxostat.  

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HGPRT enzyme. Without HGPRT, patients are unable to recycle purines. Therefore, the purines undergo metabolism into uric acid, resulting in hyperuricemia.  

Laboratory testing will demonstrate elevated serum and urinary uric acid levels. Some patients may have megaloblastic anemia despite normal serum B12 and folate level. A definitive diagnosis can be made via enzymatic testing of HGPRT or genetic testing for mutations in the HPRT1 gene.  

Treatment involves reducing uric acid levels with medications such as allopurinol or febuxostat. Both medications are xanthine oxidase inhibitors and decrease conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid.    

However, xanthine oxidase inhibitors do not prevent or treat neurodevelopmental and behavioral symptoms associated with the condition. Other interventions are needed to treat these symptoms. These include benzodiazepines and baclofen for pyramidal symptoms (e.g., spasticity), behavioral interventions (e.g., positive reinforcement), and aversive techniques (e.g., teeth guard) to prevent self-injuries.  

Option Analysis

❌ Uridine monophosphate synthase:
Incorrect: Hereditary orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a deficiency in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. The enzyme mediates the conversion of orotic acid to UMP, which is subsequently converted into the pyrimidine bases needed for DNA and RNA synthesis. Patients with hereditary orotic aciduria present with megaloblastic anemia as well as elevated serum and urinary orotic acid levels.
❌ Ornithine transcarbamylase:
Incorrect: Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of proteins in the urea cycle. Although OTC deficiency results in elevated urinary orotic acid levels, these patients also have increased ammonia levels. Furthermore, patients with OTC deficiency do not typically have megaloblastic anemia.
❌ Ribonucleotide reductase:
Incorrect: In order for nucleobases to be used in DNA synthesis, the ribose sugars need to be of the deoxy form. This step of the biochemical process is carried out by ribonucleotide reductase. While ribonucleotide reductase deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not lead to increased urinary orotic acid levels.
✅ Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thymidylate synthase.:
Incorrect: Thymidylate synthase is responsible for converting deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP). A deficiency in folate or vitamin B12 can lead to decreased thymidylate synthase activity and megaloblastic anemia. However, patients would not typically have elevated urinary orotic acid levels.
